title: Aubrey Buxton, Baron Buxton of Alsa
text:
<a href="Major%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Major</a> Aubrey Leland Oakes Buxton, Baron Buxton of Alsa (15 July 1918 – 1 September 2009) was a British soldier, politician, television executive, and writer.
Biography.
Early life.
He was born on 15 July 1918. His father was Leland William Wilberforce Buxton and his mother, Ada Mary Oakes. He was the great-great-grandson of the anti-slavery campaigner <a href="Sir%20Fowell%20Buxton%2C%201st%20Baronet">Sir Thomas Buxton</a>. He was educated at <a href="Ampleforth%20College">Ampleforth College</a> in <a href="Yorkshire">Yorkshire</a> and graduated from <a href="Trinity%20College%2C%20Cambridge">Trinity College, Cambridge</a>. He served in the <a href="Royal%20Artillery">Royal Artillery</a> in the <a href="World%20War%20II">Second World War</a> and was decorated with the <a href="Military%20Cross">Military Cross</a> in 1943.
Career.
From 1958 to 1988, he was a Director of <a href="Anglia%20Television">Anglia Television</a>. He was best known for creating the <a href="nature%20documentary">nature documentary</a> series <a href="Survival%20%28TV%20series%29">"Survival"</a>, which ran for four decades.
Philanthropy.
In 1961 he was one of the co-founders of the <a href="World%20Wide%20Fund%20for%20Nature">World Wildlife Fund</a>. As well as the WWF, he was involved with the <a href="Natural%20History%20Museum%2C%20London">Natural History Museum</a>, the <a href="Wildfowl%20and%20Wetlands%20Trust">Wildfowl and Wetlands Trust</a> and the <a href="London%20Zoological%20Society">London Zoological Society</a>. In 1976 he and Lady Buxton donated a 10 hectare estate near <a href="Elsenham">Elsenham</a> to the <a href="Essex%20Wildlife%20Trust">Essex Wildlife Trust</a>, and it is named the <a href="Aubrey%20Buxton%20Nature%20Reserve">Aubrey Buxton Nature Reserve</a>.
In 1964, he was <a href="Equerry">Extra Equerry</a> to <a href="Prince%20Philip%2C%20Duke%20of%20Edinburgh">Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh</a> and in 1972 <a href="High%20Sheriff%20of%20Essex">High Sheriff of Essex</a>. He became <a href="Lord%20Lieutenant%20of%20Essex">Deputy Lieutenant of Essex</a> in 1975 and held this office until 1985.
Peerage.
On 11 May 1978, he was created a <a href="life%20peer">life peer</a> as Baron Buxton of Alsa, "of <a href="Stiffkey">Stiffkey</a> in the <a href="County%20of%20Norfolk">County of Norfolk</a>". In 1996, Buxton, was invested as a <a href="Knight%20Commander%20of%20the%20Royal%20Victorian%20Order">Knight Commander of the Royal Victorian Order</a> (KCVO).
Personal life.
He was married twice: firstly to Pamela Mary "Maria" Birkin, daughter of <a href="Sir%20Henry%20Birkin%2C%203rd%20Baronet">Sir Henry Birkin, 3rd Baronet</a>, on 14 November 1946; and secondly (having been widowed in 1983) to Mrs. Kathleen Peterson, an American on 16 July 1988. His first marriage produced six children, one of whom, <a href="Cindy%20Buxton">Cindy Buxton</a>, is a noted filmmaker.
He died on 1 September 2009, aged 91, from undisclosed causes.
